Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of animal, maybe lion or baboon. White coating with yellow-brown paint preserved on mane. Light brown fabric with abundant fine silver mica, common quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Possibly '11' written on back in pencil. An animal, probably a lion or baboon with a few parallels (Bayer-Niemeier 1988, pl.103.6 no.588; Török 1995, pl.142, no.264, unprovenanced; Teeter 2010, no.186, 26th Dynasty from Medinet Habu). The technique iused to make this however looks to be Ptolemaic and not Late Period. Bayer-Niemeier, E. 1988. Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik. Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann, 1. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten. Melsungen. Teeter, E. 2010. Baked Clay Figurines and Votive Beds from Medinet Habu. Oriental Institute Publications 133, Chicago. Török, L. 1995. Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt. Rome.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.331) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 97, no. 343) (probably)
